climbs.name: Unknown Face Climb on Gorilla Pillar

content.description: Bolted face climb on the large pillar-like formation between Bobbing For Frogs and Hank Jr. Not sure if this is a project or a route. Viewed from Bobbing for Frogs the pillar forms a huge left facing corner, and resembles a gorilla's head, giving it the name Gorilla Pillar in the old guidebook.
content.protection: Four bolts on a face were observed. Possibly some gear down low, and in the crack between bolts three and four.
content.location: Steep face on the pillar to the right of Bobbing for Frogs.

content.description: Short, but fun!  Heel hook and hug the patina arete with remarkable rock. Beware of the flake just left of the arete (it flexes), but you may need it for a foot. Stick clip highly recommended.
content.location: Walk through tunnel, turn right up corridor. Right across the corridor from 'Flirtin' With Disaster'

climbs.name: Second Date
climbs.fa: First known ascent, Will Avent and Jordan L. 12-7-19 FFA Will Avent and Keith Wood 12-8-19

content.description: Start beside the tree up on the step, then traverse left on easy slab to the water grooves for your first pro. Follow the featured water grooves until they deepen to cracks, follow various crack systems jamming and face climbing to a 2 bolt anchor! Lots of face holds to keep it interesting with good hand and fist jams in the cracks along the way.
content.protection:
FA was completed with various nuts, singles of finger sizes and doubles of #1, #3 and a single #4. Could be lead safely with a single #3 if you were strategic.

2 bolt anchor with rappel rings at top. Put in with permission of the FA party of Hank Jr.
content.location: Immediately after the tunnel, look right and 30 feet uphill for the obvious crack systems just to the right of Hank Jr.
Alternate finish to MTV from the double bolt belay. Can rap down from above to start this pitch from the double bolts without doing Fuzz/MTV.

content.description: If you love Joshua Tree slabbin then this thing is for you. Short and action packed eagle rock knobs. Sustained and thoughtful.
content.location: Just below the lower tier

content.description:
Direct start to “Rona.”

Start on the side pulls/ feet on the quartz knobs and fire up to the mantle on Rona
content.location: Below “trial and error”

content.description: start on the lowest rail (obvious) and work left and up to a fun mantel.
content.location: below “trial and error

content.description: Three distinct cruxes but the first one is the most balancy. Second crux involves bullet hard crimps.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Some folks may want a small cam or nut to protect moves on 5.0 terrain getting to bolt 3 but most people would be comfortable with draws only. Anchors.
content.location: Start on a 15' rounded arete that is about 15' left of the more obvious start of Bobbing For Frogs.

content.description: Steep 90 degree wall with continual variety. Go get it. Locate a bolt 15 feet up (stick clip advised). Pull the bouldery start moves past the bolt, work up and left to a friction crux. Great edges and jams up top to anchors. Note: all of Eagle Rock was highly affected by the 2017 fires. Climbing has also been closed here for 15 years, open in May 2018 thanks to the CCC (join them if you are reading this). Bring a brush to dust off ash. Like many other Eagle routes, once clean, this is a fantastic route.
content.location: Lower Tier, far left side. This is found 30' left of the route Eagle Scratch, the obvious angling crack.

climbs.name: MTV (More Than Vertical)
climbs.fa: Keith Wood, Tommy Bridges 5.10b A0, 1989; FFA Adam Tripp, 2020

content.protection: Trad, some bolts, hooks for aid in drilled holes.
content.location: Prominent dihedral in the middle of the Fuzz Ledge. Climb King Wing, Horus, or Fuzz's Fire Insurance to get on the Fuzz ledge. Can access the ledge from Bobbing for Frogs or Poet's Return as well.

content.description:
very fun route with distinct style sections in consistent difficulty. move left up the textured slab to the lengthwise crack/undercrimp (may want stick clip for some high gear here). sidepull to gain an excellent pinch and mantle onto the shelf. from right shelf, take another high clip and hand/foot match a steep series of 3 or 4 thin crosswise sloping edges til mantle up under the anchor at far left of huge shelf with Fuzz Fire Insurance over to right.

if you're short on gear you can easily set for TR after topping Fuzz Fire.
content.location: middle of the lower tier, as the path begins to get steeper and sketchier. about 20' left of Fuzz Fire Insurance's clear thin crack with vegetation on shelf at top. see photo for better reference.

climbs.name: Jonah
climbs.fa: Sean Cobourn, Candus Wester and Kyle Sox

content.description: Squeeze up the obvious chimney to the roof.  Stay away from tottering loose blocks.  Pull hard moves and traverse roof out right until you can fit yourself into the slot.  Tunnel through the belly of the beast to a sling belay at other side.  An odd but fun endeavor, done onsight, ground up.
content.protection: bolts and cams from 1 to 4" or bigger if you have some.
content.location: on south side of buttress a hundred yards or so into the jungle past the Tunnel Trail.

content.description: Tons of variety on this one. Start on slab passing 3 bolts to where the wall steepens. There make some thin crimp moves to jugs, dead point to more jugs, plug some pro in the horizontal, move left through the crux then to amazing steep face climbing and a final heartbreaker move before the final mantle. Once on the ledge you will feel one with the bird headed god.
content.protection: Mostly bolts with a couple pieces of small gear. Shares King Wing anchor.
content.location: 20' right of King Wing.

content.description: Best done in two pitches. Finish first pitch by traversing the horizontal crack and belay from the left facing flake which takes good pro, or the new anchors at the top of Second Date. 6 to 8 bolts depending how you go and a few small cams/nuts to fixed anchors above the lip (rap rings not visible from ground). This route starts just left of the cracks of Second Date. It begins up a run-out but relatively easy arete to the first bolt (visible from ground ~30 ft up), and then moves into balance intensive slabby face climbing.  The bolt lines split off in different directions near the top, or you could split off up through the vegetated gully.  This one sports some old and new bolts, and it is definitely a rope stretcher.  Great thrill!
content.protection: bolts and small nuts/cams;  fixed anchors with rings
content.location: Go through tunnel, immediately turn right, and its' the first route to sport bolts on the left.

content.description: Thin crack. A neat lie back move or two. We have dusted it off a bit but it may need more.
content.protection: gear, some small nuts, anchors up and left
content.location: Walk through Tunnel, then follow base downhill, then back uphill. This route is an obvious weakness to a ledge. In 2017, the Carolina Climbers Coalition conducted a cliff biological survey (this was one of the requirements to have legal climbing access expanded within Chimney Rock State Park). During the survey, we found a patch of Granite Dome Goldenrod under the anchors, where you would rap. We moved the anchor further up and left for this reason. They are easy to reach once you hit the ledge and can serve as a belay point for second pitch routes leaving from the Fuzz Ledge.

Up the steep gully left of New Kid in Town. Route is where two roof slabs overlap in different directions with a prominent flake below. Do not scramble further up the steep gully to hike out from the base as it is not an authorized trail, and has some broken glass here and there.

content.description:
At the east end of lower Eagle Rock is a giant boulder forming a tunnel where it abuts the main wall. From atop the tunnel follow a natural feature upwards around 1 o'clock. It becomes a mixed line with some bolts. Once you hit the woods, scramble/bushwhack to the summit.

Bolts recently replaced by Carolina Climbers Coalition. Sent free at 11b. Great crack to techy crux.
content.location: East end of lower tier, above tunnel feature.

content.description: This was not given a name to my knowledge. Tim, Sean- feel free to update.Sweet left slanting crack with a surprise crux in the bulge leading to anchors. There is a Tim Snyder/ Sean Cobourn project that continues (note bolt above anchors) but currently unfinished. It will need more dusting off. This area was heavily affected by the 2017 fires so the next year plus will require ash cleaning. Keith Wood notes: In 1989 Keith Wood and Tommy Bridges gave this a shot but couldn't complete it. It blanks out above the bulge. We drilled a bolt hole but didn't put in the last bolt because it didn't look like it could go any further. Our name for it was Noncommittal Mugging, but it really should be named by the one that completes it.
content.location: This route is on the Lower Tier of Eagle. Walk the amazing Tunnel Trail, CRSP's newest trail created by a partnership between the Carolina Climbers Coalition, Chimney Rock State Park, and Conserving Carolina. Follow the Tunnel Trail through the tunnel, then keep walking straight, past the newly made stone sofa, and follow along the base of the cliff.

content.description:
P1: 5.8+ Nice moderate that should serve as the warm up for the Lower Tier. Climb past three bolts and gear. The top has some neat knobs. If climbing P2, you may want to belay just left of the bush. CCC volunteers replaced the lead bolts in 2018.

P2: 5.10a Great slabbin'! Climb wide flake behing bush, move right for bolt 1, then follow 4 more bolts and gear to an anchor. All bolts replaced by CCC on this pitch, 2019.
content.protection: gear, some bolts, anchors on both pitches.
content.location: Once you walk through the Tunnel via the Tunnel Trail, continue straight past the stone sofa and down hill to the toe of the Lower Tier. This route is the right-most of two lines on this lower slab

content.description:
Follows great flakes with solid pro to a shared anchor with Flirtin' With Disaster at 90'. This would deserve more stars with some cleaning of ash from fires.

This flake system was once hidden by foliage, but the fires of 2017 revealed it.
content.location: Walk through tunnel. Head uphill and right, into the corridor. Find the flake system 15' Left of Flirtin' With DIsaster.
